awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Rhizosphere Control of Soil Carbon Protection on Mineral Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Storage of carbon in soil is of high interest to ecosystem scientists because it enhances soil fertility and potentially decreases the production of gases like carbon dioxide and methane. Plant roots provide the major input of soil carbon, transferring carbon dioxide captured from the atmosphere into the soil system. Microorganisms in the soil are the primary consumers and decomposers of this carbon, and can transform it back into carbon dioxide, or into methane. It follows that the part of the soil where microorganisms come in contact with plant roots is a hotspot for carbon transformation. This graduate student research research project will follow the fate of root-derived carbon in soil, examining the role of soil microbial communities and associated soil minerals in carbon stabilization. The project will involve collaboration with scientists at national laboratories and promote participation of students from under-represented groups in the research. 

While carbon (C) association with soil minerals is thought to be a critical step in soil C stabilization, the underlying mechanisms - particularly in the persistence of mineral-carbon associations - are poorly understood. The student will grow the common annual grass, Avena barbata, (wild oat) under a 13CO2 atmosphere in soil microcosms, thus enabling her to follow the fate of the root-derived C. Using a technique called stable isotope probing (SIP), she will trace the 13C derived from the plant into soil microbes and on to soil minerals. In this project, the researchers will investigate how the longer term fate of C, present on minerals or in soil microorganisms is effected by the presence or absence of A. barbata. The research will examine (1) the fate of mineral-associated C, (2) the influence of mineralogy, (3) the influence of the rhizosphere, the zone of plant root influence, and (4) the role of the microbial community. By constraining both the mechanisms of mineral-C association and persistence, the researchers can begin to understand and quantify the importance of these associations in C cycling and environmental change models.

por.por_cntn:
Mineral surfaces provide sites for carbon (C) protection in soils, the largest active terrestrial C reservoir. Mineral-associated C may persist for thousands of year, isolating a critical pool of soil C from microbial degradation and the subsequent release of reactive greenhouse gases (CO2, CH4). While mineral-association of C is thought to be critical mode of soil C stabilization, the mechanisms controlling the persistence of mineral-carbon associations is poorly understood. Most prior research on mineral-C association has focused either on abiotic mechanisms, or used bulk soil (soil not closely associated with plant roots). We know that soil microorganisms are the central drivers of C transformation in soil, and as the majority of global surface soil is vegetated, that the rhizosphere is a nexus for surface soil transformations. The intellectual meritof this work was to fill critical gaps in our understanding of the mechanisms controlling persistence of mineral-associated C, looking at the influence of mineralogy, plant growth, and the soil microbial community. Plants are the primary source of C in soil, with roots exuding low-molecular weight compounds during growth and contributing more complex litter compounds after senescence. 

 

We conducted two complimentary experiments, with: (1) minerals incubated adjacent to an active rhizosphere (zone of root growth), and (2) minerals incubated in soil with root litter. Both experiments had a control treatment without added plant C (rhizosphere or litter). We find that mineralogy dictates the total C associated with mineral surfaces, and that pure minerals (quartz, ferrihydrite-coated quartz, and kaolinite) had an order of magnitude less C than native soil minerals, suggesting the long incubation time needed to form these C-mineral associations in soil. We determined that a third of the mineral-associated C in the rhizosphere experiment was from the actively growing plant, while the remainder was derived from older soil C pools in the bulk soil. Carbon associated with minerals incubated in the rhizosphere had a distinct compositional fingerprint from those in the control treatment with no plant, suggesting that not only mineralogy, but also C source may play an important role in determining the persistence of soil C. A large portion of mineral-associated C was lipid, particularly in the control treatment with no plant. FTICR-MS on the soluble fraction of mineral-associated C showed few lipids from any minerals type, which is consistent with previous work showing that lipids may be highly persistent on mineral surfaces. Lipidomics showed that while a portion of these lipids were derived from the plant, the majority were microbial. We found that mineral-associated, or “mineralosphere” microbial community composition was shaped by mineralogy. The mineralosphere microbial community may play an important role in shaping the composition of mineral-associated C. Thus, the interaction of mineralogy, C source, and the microbial community appear to influence the ultimate persistence of mineral-associated C. 

 

This research promoted teaching, training, and learning through incorporation of undergraduate students in the project. UC Berkeley undergraduate students assisted in microcosm sampling and analytical analyses post-harvest. Many of these students were from under-represented groups, helping to broaden participation. Collaborative work on this project as a Lawrence Graduate Scholar and with shared efforts at three government national laboratories, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, enhanced infrastructure for research and education. Through presentation of work at scientific conferences and preparation for publication of results in peer-reviewed journals, we helped to broaden dissemination of scientific understanding. The focus of this research on C dynamics and stabilization in soils is directly linked to the issue of climate change, as soils are the largest active terrestrial C reservoir. This project has benefits to societyin addressing knowledge gaps in how C associates and then persists with mineral surfaces.
